discussion.content: B is the answer

questions.question_text:
A business owner wants to provide security to laptop users with the ability to charge their devices, access corporate LAN resources, and allow for a variety of other removable hardware.
Which of the following devices would BEST meet the owner's needs?
Which of the following server types caches previously visited web pages for faster access in the future?

discussion.content:
BranchCache is a wide area network (WAN) bandwidth optimization technology that is included in some editions of the Windows Server 2016 and Windows 10 operating systems, as well as in some editions of Windows Server 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2012, Windows 8, Windows Server 2008 R2 and Windows 7. To optimize WAN bandwidth when users access content on remote servers, BranchCache fetches content from your main office or hosted cloud content servers and caches the content at branch office locations, allowing client computers at branch offices to access the content locally rather than over the WAN.

Use is more for offices with different branches storing different resources once accessed so that it doesn't need to be retrieved via the cloud or other medium repeatedly. Proxy servers perform a similar function for web pages visited and is the correct answer.

comments.content: Exactly what I found on Microsoft website, so Branch Cache Server is the correct answer, but the thing is I've never seen this topic covered by A+. It could be one of these questions A+ add to the exam for a test purpose where it is not marked at the end!

discussion.content: Branch Server is nowhere mentioned in A+.

I am saying D because the branche cache is available on the local network therefore quicker to access than the proxy server. The proxy server can cache too but the local cache is quicker than sending a request to the intermediary and waiting for a response. The proxy gets you request then sends it to the server with the data. the server sends a response to the proxy which then has to send you the response. Sending from your computer (the client) straight to the server should be faster as there is no middle man and less steps.

Selected Answer: A
A proxy server is used primarily as a go-between for the client and the website accessed. It is commonly used to cache information so that another user accessing the same web page won’t have to get it from the Internet, because it already exists on the proxy server, which increases general performance and efficiency.

its proxy server; 
as per A+ Exam Cram Book: "A proxy server is used primarily as a go-between for the client and the website
accessed. It is commonly used to cache information so that another user
accessing the same web page won’t have to get it from the Internet, because
it already exists on the proxy server, which increases general performance
and efficiency."
I don't see anything about Branch Cache anywhere in the book, not even in the index, so I'm going with "A."

the answer is wrong. 
Answer is A. proxy server

Only source content - that is, content that client computers initially obtain from a BranchCache-enabled content server - is accelerated by BranchCache. Content that client computers obtain directly from other sources, such as Web servers on the Internet or Windows Update, is not cached by client computers or hosted cache servers and then shared with other computers in the branch office.
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/windows-server/networking/branchcache/branchcache
Think it is proxy server since to cache web content the web server needs to support branch cache server and it needs to be configured. Proxy server will cache all web sites without additional software installed and configured.

https://blog.stackpath.com/proxy-caching/
Answer is A

comments.content: Agree, if this is a more general question not tied with a specific tecnology or SO - I believe Proxy Server is the most correct one

discussion.content:
The proxy server should be the correct answer. Branch Cache is not a server but a feature found in Windows OS and server. 
Note: nowhere in the question mentions Window's server.
DNS server managed by IPS or an enterprise IT department. In case on SOHO it would be Proxy server Ans is A .

comments.content:
I think Proxy server is correct answer:
This is one of the definition of Branch Cache:
BranchCache caches file, web, and application content at branch office locations, allowing client computers to access data using the local area network (LAN) rather than accessing the content over slow WAN connections.

this is example of Proxy server:
For example, when a visitor accesses a blog with a header image, the proxy server looks for the image in its cache. If it’s the first time that the image is accessed, the server needs to request it from the origin. The next time the article is accessed from the proxy server – by any visitor – the image will already be available in the proxy cache.

discussion.content: Branch Cache server is correct. It increases web query response time for clients and servers. Proxy server provides security by masking our identity on the internet
A proxy server is responsible for Web caching.

comments.content: I would have to agree with you. Although a proxy server can be configured to cache frequently requested pages, I think that the A+ would more generally want the technician to know that the DNS server is where the cache is stored. I don't remember any of the A+ content revolving around managing, or flushing, proxy caches. As compared to the material covered in troubleshooting the DNS cache.
DNS server is storing entries to an FQDN table mapping those FQDN's to IP addresses. It isn't caching ever page it encounters like a proxy server would.

discussion.content: why is it not DNS server?

I agree that it could be Proxy server, and that BanchCache Server is not covered in A+. However, Proxy server is used in Enterprise environments, where the users log-in to certain web pages, and the Proxy servers saves those websites for faster access for other users. It creates a cache. BanchCache Server is general use.

Upon research, I found out the Branchcache exists but that I know is not covered in the A+ objectives. I don't know why it's even listed as an option.

https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/windows-server/networking/branchcache/branchcache

I agree!
Does it even exist that "Branch Cache Server"? I never heard of it before.
Proxy server (A) of course!

comments.content: This is the best explanation, because this explanation is short and to the point.

discussion.content:
He has only 3 drives so that excludes: RAID 10
Does not say anything about redundancy so that excludes: RAID 5
Needs the fastest option; that excludes: RAID 1

Correct: RAID 0 (striping) fastest

comments.content: Thank you for the detailed explanation, I agree it has to be RAID 0 for speed

discussion.content:
Why not the Raid 1,5 and 10(1+0).
Raid 1 is called mirror, which means copy of a copy and no quick access. (redundancy)

Raid 5 is similar to raid 0 but raid 5 has PARITY which is a piece of data that is used to rebuilt blocks in case of a disk failure, which means no full storage capacity but quick access.

Raid 10 is the ultimate of redundancy and performance but it Requires at least 4 disks in order to work (2 for raid 0 functionality and 2 for raid 1 functionality)

why Raid 0 is correct?

Raid 0 offers fastest access and highest capacity but not REDUNDANCY, NO PARITY. 

This is an animated video that will answer this question and clear doubts: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=U-OCdTeZLac
Doesn't say anything about fault-tolerant or redundancy so Raid 0! It's the fastest and most storage.

RAID 0 = Striped volume (min 2 drives) (NOT fault tolerant)(speed)
RAID 1 = Mirrored (min 2 drives) (fault tolerant)(relatifly expansive) 
RAID 5 = Striped with parity volume (min 3 drives) (has fault tolerants)(good reading)
It said he has three but that doesn't mean he's going to use all, I believe. tricky one
RAID 0 is the correct choice

1+0 
He has only 3 drives so that excludes: RAID 10
Also says nothing about redundancy either. So RAID 1 has to be correct

comments.content: Acc the keyword here is "most capacity" too, as RAID 0 offers zero loss of space on disks. RAID 1, 5 & 1+0 on the other hand, reduce the capacity up to 50%. This was explained in one of "Dion Training" on Udemy course, very helpful when answering some A+ questions.

discussion.content: RAID 0 is the correct choice. The keyword here is fast access

comments.content: You need a minimum of 4 hard-drives for hybrid RAIDs

Hey stilcurt,

no. 
As there are only 3 drives available RAID 10 will not work, as these needs 4 Disks minimum
RAID 5 will not the correct one as Fast and much space is requested and no comment on redudancy… so RAID 0 is here the correct choice.

Regards

discussion.content: I thought the answer to this question is raid 10.

questions.question_text: Joe, a user, wants his desktop RAID configured to allow the fastest speed and the most storage capacity. His desktop has three hard drives. Which of the following RAID types should a technician configure to achieve this?

An employee's laptop will not power on. When the power button is pressed, the power light goes on and then suddenly off. A technician replaces the battery, and the laptop powers on. The employee works without issues until the end of the day, but the laptop presents the same problem the next morning.
Which of the following is the MOST probable cause of the issue?

comments.content: True, because of the damaged charger, the replacement battery never got a proper charge that night and died the next day.

discussion.content:
Damaged AC adapter is the most correct answer. Most likely the adapter is not charging the battery or possibly damaging it.
Swollen battery is incorrect as the battery has already been replaced, and the issue is occurring again.
Improperly seated RAM would likely cause the computer to fail to boot, but not impact power.
Fan failure is incorrect as the shutdown would have occurred sooner on the same day and not immediately on the following day.
Hard drive failure is incorrect as the issue did not replicate immediately upon replacing the battery. Hard drive failure would likely cause a crash rather than force a shutdown.
I would have expected the technician to check the AC adapter first before replacing the battery.

questions.question_text: A bank employee contacts the help desk for assistance with setting up a new computer. Which of the following peripherals will the technician MOST likely install alongside the device? (Choose two.)

discussion.content: Magnetic Reader and signature pad, you have to read the magnetic strip on IDs/Debit cards and also provide signatures..

comments.content: Yes , but I have seen those special keyboards that have magnetic strip prebuilt along with on the keyboard in some banks.

upon doing further research, all bank tellers have webcams installed at their stations to monitor their activities for fraudulent practices and teller theft. So, signature pad, and webcam is, unbelievably enough, correct. This is a question only people in the industry would likely know.

discussion.content: Why does a bank employee need a web camera to be installed on his computer and not a flatbed scanner?

The 7th said reader and magnetic swipe. Gonna stick to B, D,

I would think B. Signature pad and C. Flatbed scanner. Both would be used often in a bank setting. A web camera is often used in an office setting as well but I don't think it would supersede the previous two.
